results.title: Visual perception and failure to learn
results.creator_credit: Charles M. Wurst, Churchill Films and Columbia Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the effects of different visual perceptual disabilities upon the performance and behaviour of children in a regular classroom and in a centre for remedial education.

results.title: Seven little Australians: Eps. 4-6
results.creator_credit: Ron Way, Charles Russell, ABC and Ethel Turner Productions
results.brief_description: The story of the Woolcot family, living in Sydney in the 1890’s. An Englishman in the New South Wales Regiment, Captain Woolcot is constantly harassed and embarrassed by the antics of his seven mischievous children: Meg, Pip, Judy, Nell, Bunty, Baby and ‘The General’. Episode 4: All for the worst: Bunty is plagued by the lies he tells, Meg makes efforts to be ‘grown up’ and Judy makes a tortuous trip home. Episode 5: Secrets: Judy arrives home worn out and ill, but makes the other children promise not to let Esther or the Captain know for fear of being sent back to school. Episode 6: Tomorrow do thy worst: Judy is still ill and the children try to take care of her. However, the Captain’s suspicions are aroused and he discovers Judy’s hiding place.

results.title: Wolf pack
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A nature film that shows the absorbing, even admirable qualities of the wolf’s character and behavior, and its essential role in the natural scheme of life and death. Filmed by Bill Mason in caribou country, Wolf Pack closely observes the wolves through late winter into early spring. What emerges is a portrait of the wolf as a disciplined hunter, a respected leader, and a parent whose care for the young ensures the survival of the pack.

results.title: Wolf [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Andrew Duval, Bin Li, Janet Hines and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A woman living somewhere in the Australian high plains tends to her horses and gardens while something out of sight lurks. The woman has fantasies about a stranger who she desires to be with but also fears to be with and the line between fantasy and reality merge as she encounters the stranger in her house. This is a beautifully filmed short film that echoes the tale of “Little Red Riding Hood”. (Awards: Winner, Silver Award for Cinematography in a Short Film, NSW Australian Cinematographers Society Awards, Sydney, 1998)

results.title: Sex mission = Seksmisja [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Juliusz Machulski and Polish Corporation for Film Production
results.brief_description: When Professor Victor Kuppelweiser wishes to test his cryogenic experiments for the first time on human beings he has two willing volunteers. Both scientists, a mis-matched pair Albert Starski and Maximilian Paradys (Jerzy Stuhr, Olgierd Lukaszewicz), are hoping for historical recognition and fame. But the experiment goes wrong and our heroes find themselves awoken (53 years later) by a post-nuclear society containing only women - who hate men. This slapstick comedy rather than implying any feminist critique pokes fun at totalitarianism, ironic in that the first-time director, Juliusz Machulski, made this film using state money in a communist country under martial law. A hilarious film that pokes fun at the values of the day by talking about tomorrow and borrows much of its stylings from films such as “Barbarella”, “The Sleeper” and thematically from films like “1984” and “Fahrenheit 451.”

results.title: Wives and daughters
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Renton, Sue Birtwistle and BBC
results.brief_description: A 19th century soap opera of splendid proportions. A story of a father remarrying for the sake of his daughter. The complications begin. A new step mother, a step sister and a selfish governess, the story unfolds. Elizabeth Gaskells unfinished novel adapted to a satisfying and beautiful series. Cast includes Michael Gambon, Francesa Annis and Ian Carmichael.

results.title: Without a sound
results.creator_credit: Michael Henry, University of Melbourne, Victorian College of the Arts and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Thomas is an insurance investigator called out on the eve of his wife leaving, to attend a mysterious fire in which an unknown boy has been killed. Going through the motions while awaiting a call from his wife, Thomas - like the viewer, is drawn into the mysteries of the fire. (Awards: Best Cinematography, nominated Best Film, Best Sound, VCA, 1998)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Henry, University of Melbourne, Victorian College of the Arts and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television

results.title: Withnail & I
results.creator_credit: Bruce Robinson, Paul Heller and HandMade Films
results.brief_description: Screenwriter Bruce Robinson made his directorial debut with this British comedy which portrays the last throes of an eccentric friendship during the final days of the sixties. Withnail and “I” (or Marwood) are both unsuccessful and unemployed actors. Bound together by poverty and dreams of stardom, they share a flat of indescribable squalor and live on a diet of alcohol, pills and pot. Withnail is fast becoming a burned-out relic of the sixties, while Marwood is trying to reassimilate into society. The two decide to spend a soul-cleansing week in the country in a primitive cottage borrowed from Withnail’s eccentric uncle Monty, but things go from worse to even worse and their dreams of an idyllic retreat rapidly degenerate into an hilarious nightmare. Cast includes Richard E. Grant, Paul McGann, Richard Griffiths, Ralph Brown and Michael Elphick.

results.title: Uluru: an Anangu story (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This is the history of Uluru from an aboriginal perspective, from the dawn of creation to the celebrations on October 26, 1985, when Uluru was handed back to the traditional owners. Presented with humour and sensitivity are re-enactments of the creation stories, the experience of the Anangu during their first contact with white people and minga (tourists) performing their strange rituals.
